block.p: International A3-13 'NO' TO UNION IN CANADA Voters in Canada rejected a constitutional package intended to strengthen union and, in particular, to end Quebec's drive for succession. The confederation is not likely to dissolve soon, but Quebec may gain some sovereignty. A1 HINTS OF BRITISH ROLE IN IRAQ . . . Britain, in exchange for intelligence, helped Iraq build up its military before Kuwait was invaded. A1

International A3-13 'NO' TO UNION IN CANADA Voters in Canada rejected a constitutional package intended to strengthen union and, in particular, to end Quebec's drive for succession. The confederation is not likely to dissolve soon, but Quebec may gain some sovereignty. A1 HINTS OF BRITISH ROLE IN IRAQ . . . Britain, in exchange for intelligence, helped Iraq build up its military before Kuwait was invaded. A1

. . . AND U.S. TRANSACTIONS The Bush Administration in 1989 approved the export to Iraq of two computers with potential military applications. A13 TALES FROM THE DYNASTIC BOUDOIR The Japanese Emperor asked some public questions about China's intimate history on his visit to the Forbidden City. A3 ISRAEL RETALIATES WITH BOMBS Israeli artillery, aircraft and gunboats pounded Lebanon in retaliation for a bomb ambush by Islamic fundamentalists that killed five. A8 CZECHS AND SLOVAKS IN ACCORD In preparation for their eventual separation, the Czech and Slovak republics agreed on a blueprint for customs, agriculture and foreign currencies. A6 NEW POWER FOR OLD LEADERS After years of fighting for autonomy from the Soviet Union, Lithuanians handed power back to the former Communists in country's first elections since independence. A10 TENSION SPLITS BOSNIAN FORCES Fissures are spreading through the Government of Bosnia as it becomes clear that an alliance of Muslims and Croats is not in the offing. A10 SALVADOR REBELS AGREE TO PLAN Leaders of Salvadoran rebels said they would accede to U.N. deadlines for demobilizing their forces -- under one condition. A9 NEW TAXES IN BONN'S CRYSTAL BALL Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said tax increases by 1995 were inevitable because of the high costs of rebuilding East Germany. A11 WHOEVER IS IN THE WHITE HOUSE . . . European leaders say they have no qualms about the possibility of a Clinton Administration in Washington and in fact seem more concerned about their own survival. A12 IRAQI KURDS CLAIM A VICTORY Iraqi Kurds said they took the main base of separatist Turkish Kurds in northern Iraq. A12 A bitter taste in the mouths of "alimentari" owners. A11 Ireland debates wording of abortion referndum. A8 Santo Domingo Journal: Divergent earthly paths to heaven. A4 National A14-21 PEROT CONTINUES ACCUSATIONS Perot continued suggesting there had been a Republican plot to smear his daughter, and a spokesman for the President called the independent candidate "paranoid." A1 F.B.I. LOOKED INTO PEROT CHARGE Administration officials said the F.B.I. sent an agent to the office of the Bush campaign chairman in Texas in an effort to check out Perot's accusation that Republicans were spying on him. A1 BUSH CALLS HIMSELF 'ACTIVIST' Bush took a break from his attacks on Clinton to address voter discontent, painting himself as a "conservative activist" who has the best attributes of Perot and Clinton. A1 CHRISTIAN CANDIDATES GAIN Across the country, conservative Christian candidates are building on several years of organizing to mount strong challenges for elected positions minor and major. A1 CLINTON TALKS CONSERVATIVE Trying to reach independent, essentially conservative voters, Clinton sounded a theme heavy with values associated with conservatism. A20 KEY CAMPAIGN ISSUES AVOIDED Through the many months of speeches and campaign appearances, the candidates have left many crucial issues unexplored. A21 Perot has again thrown the Presidential race into disarray. A18 The candidates are engaged in the costliest ad blitz ever.A19 Perot's well-watched TV ads seem to defy political experience. A19 Stan Greenberg, Clinton's poll taker, has come a long way. A20 G.M. CHAIRMAN RESIGNS Robert Stempel resigned as chairman and chief executive of General Motors, amid speculation that his dismissal was imminent and continuing losses at the company. A1 ADS ON ABORTION BECOME CRUCIAL Television commercials on abortion are becoming more and more important to candidates running for the House and Senate. A14 REFERENDUM PUSHES RECYCLING Environmentalists in Massachusetts are campaigning for the most sweeping recycling measure in the country. A15 Researchers in Mississippi are trying to lure back bald eagles. A14 The E.P.A. moved to curb chemicals that cause acid rain. A16 Two unusual candidates are running for Congress in Madison, Wis. A14 Science Times C1-10 What makes a perception? Scientists think seriously about it. C1 The space station has so far stayed mostly on the drawing board. C1 A comet may hit, but not until 2126. C7 Metro Digest B1 DINKINS AIDE STEPS ASIDE Randy Daniels withdrew as a deputy mayor of New York City, indicating that his effectiveness as an adviser to Mayor Dinkins had been destroyed by allegations that he sexually harassed a woman who worked for him five years ago. A1 Business Digest D1 Fashion Page B9 Arts/Entertainment C13-18 The Talk of Hollywood. C13 A photographic movement. C13 Sports B10-16 Baseball: Mets obtain Tony Fernandez. B11 Hockey: Rangers beat Flyers. B11 Obituaries B7-8 Roger Miller, country singer. B8 Editorials/Op-Ed A22-23 Editorials Getting dizzy with Ross Perot. The children left behind. Sex harassment, men in power. For Congress from New Jersey. Letters A. M. Rosenthal: Perot's little helpers. Russell Baker: The future foretold. Greil Marcus: The Elvis strategy. Hiroyuki Kishino: No fear. The plutonium's safe.
